title: Update about Chapter 25 Plus a Therapy Tip

transcript_parts.text: hi there this is a little update about
why you didn't see on Sunday I wanted to
give you an explanation as to why I
didn't release chapter 25 of the reading
video on Sunday the reason is I
accidentally erased my entire commentary
everything I've written so I started to
rewrite it thinking I could you know
easily recreate it but the problem is 24
25 and 26 are really critical chapters
to understanding how to implement pr6
philosophy in life and for my particular
project that makes them exceptionally
important 26 I think it especially 25 is
something that Pierce had considered one
of the most important chapters so I'm
going to put it out next Sunday and then
26 the week after I need the extra time
for these so thanks for bearing with me
so that's my explanation on those
secondly I want to share something I
guess you would call it a therapy tip
but I think it's a little deeper than
that and this is sort of along the lines
of Buddhism so you know probably the
Buddhist Buddhism of course it's a world
religion but it's also an underlying
structure of it psychology and the
Buddhist practices are very much like
psychotherapy there's an interesting
food a story about a zen monk who was
who his acolyte didn't wake him up on
time to do his service and so when he
wakes up he's really pissed off and the
acolyte says but but today's Saturday he
goes oh okay if he goes back to sleep
the point is that negative emotion is
part of who we are and Zen and Buddhist
practice isn't so much headed towards a
goal of serenity peacefulness and a sage
demeanor what these practices are when
enlightenment is is is to be yourself
but be accepting of it it doesn't mean
you're going to say oh well that means I
can do anything you know I can be as
cruel as I like I can just rob banks or
whatever no it doesn't mean that what it
means is you understand that positive
and negative emotions are two sides of
the same coin and you're not suppressing
your negative emotion or accepting of
them obviously if you if you do
something to hurt someone you're going
to apologize obviously you're not going
to intentionally hurt someone that's not
going to happen in an enlightened person
but it does mean that you will at times
express negative emotion so you're going
to embarrass yourself and you're going
to do all these things um let's just say
if you're enlightened person you're
going to be able to handle being
embarrassed and you're going to be able
to handle people not liking you being
angry at you and you being angry at
things and I think that what it is is a
removal of the neuroticism around
neuroticism and it's a way of accepting
the totality of who you are remember
we're we're human beings but we're only
one neocortex removed from from our
animal from our emotional nature this is
part of us so one thing about piercing
is it's not about how things manifest in
the world it's about connecting to
quality and what follows from that is
what should be if you are connected with
quality that's what these three chapters
are about about how what how what that
pre intellectual awareness the quality
is and how to connect with it and how to
stay connected to it so I think the
point I'm making and also remember look
at Alan Watts discussion of Carl Jung
and how Carl Jung accepted himself the
way he was not not whether he
had appropriate behavior in terms of
what society expects Corleone just was
himself so I think accepting the
totality of your range of emotions and
the totality of everything in your
boxcars as human being is a lot of what
enlightenment is about so that's this is
a critical difference it's not a man if
it's not heading towards a manifestation
of something it's the process of
becoming the sort of person who is
balanced with an armed harmonious and
congruent with everything naturally are
so I hope that made sense and I will see
you next Sunday for chapter 25
you
